abstract: Estimated half-million remaining Holocaust survivors around world face unique problems in addition to those typically associated with aging; among them are fear of institutionalization, renewed anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe and lack of family; situation leads to growing need for services such as in-home care, but funding for survivors is dwindling worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Aging and often infirm and isolated, the remaining survivors require more help even as traditional sources of funding are starting to taper off.

headline.main: Holocaust Survivors’ Needs Grow, and Aid Is Slow to Catch Up
headline.print_headline: Aid for Holocaust Survivors Lags Behind Rising Needs
